pages.title: Series multisection
pages.text:
In mathematics, a '''multisection''' of a power series is a new [[power series]] composed of equally spaced terms extracted unaltered from the original series. Formally, if one is given a power series

: <math>\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty a_n\cdot z^n</math>

then its multisection is a power series of the form

: <math>\sum_{m=-\infty}^\infty a_{qm+p}\cdot z^{qm+p}</math>

where ''p'', ''q'' are integers, with 0 ≤ ''p'' < ''q''.

== Multisection of analytic functions ==
A multisection of the series of an [[analytic function]]

: <math>f(z) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n\cdot z^n</math>

has a [[closed-form expression]] in terms of the function <math>f(x)</math>:

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty a_{qm+p}\cdot z^{qm+p} = \frac{1}{q}\cdot \sum_{k=0}^{q-1} \omega^{-kp}\cdot f(\omega^k\cdot z),</math>

where <math>\omega = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{q}}</math> is a [[Primitive nth root of unity|primitive ''q''-th root of unity]].  This solution was first discovered by [[Thomas Simpson]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Simpson |first1=Thomas |date=1757 |title=CIII. The invention of a general method for determining the sum of every 2d, 3d, 4th, or 5th, &c. term of a series, taken in order; the sum of the whole series being known |url= |journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London |volume=51 |pages=757-759 |doi=10.1098/rstl.1757.0104}}</ref>  This expression is especially useful in that it can convert an infinite sum into a finite sum.  It is used, for example, in a key step of a standard proof of [[Gauss's digamma theorem]], which gives a closed-form solution to the digamma function evaluated at rational values ''p''/''q''.

== Examples ==

===Bisection===
In general, the bisections of a series are the [[even and odd functions|even and odd]] parts of the series.

===Geometric series===
Consider the [[geometric series]]

: <math>\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} z^n=\frac{1}{1-z} \quad\text{ for }|z| < 1.</math>

By setting <math>z \rightarrow z^q</math> in the above series, its multisections are easily seen to be

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} z^{qm+p} = \frac{z^p}{1-z^q} \quad\text{ for }|z| < 1.</math>

Remembering that the sum of the multisections must equal the original series, we recover the familiar identity

: <math>\sum_{p=0}^{q-1} z^p = \frac{1-z^q}{1-z}.</math>

===Exponential function===
The exponential function

: <math>e^z=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} {z^n \over n!}</math>

by means of the above formula for analytic functions separates into

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{qm+p} \over (qm+p)!} = \frac{1}{q}\cdot \sum_{k=0}^{q-1} \omega^{-kp} e^{\omega^k z}.</math>

The bisections are trivially the [[hyperbolic function]]s:

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{2m} \over (2m)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(e^z+e^{-z}\right) = \cosh{z}</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{2m+1} \over (2m+1)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(e^z-e^{-z}\right) = \sinh{z}.</math>

Higher order multisections are found by noting that all such series must be real-valued along the real line.  By taking the real part and using standard trigonometric identities, the formulas may be written in explicitly real form as

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{qm+p} \over (qm+p)!} = \frac{1}{q}\cdot \sum_{k=0}^{q-1} e^{z\cos(2\pi k/q)}\cos{\left(z\sin{\left(\frac{2\pi k}{q}\right)}-\frac{2\pi kp}{q}\right)}.</math>

These can be seen as solutions to the [[linear differential equation]] <math>f^{(q)}(z)=f(z)</math> with [[boundary conditions]] <math>f^{(k)}(0)=\delta_{k,p}</math>, using [[Kronecker delta]] notation.  In particular, the trisections are

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{3m} \over (3m)!} = \frac{1}{3}\left(e^z+2e^{-z/2}\cos{\frac{\sqrt{3}z}{2}}\right)</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{3m+1} \over (3m+1)!} = \frac{1}{3}\left(e^z-e^{-z/2}\left(\cos{\frac{\sqrt{3}z}{2}}-\sqrt{3}\sin{\frac{\sqrt{3}z}{2}}\right)\right)</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{3m+2} \over (3m+2)!} = \frac{1}{3}\left(e^z-e^{-z/2}\left(\cos{\frac{\sqrt{3}z}{2}}+\sqrt{3}\sin{\frac{\sqrt{3}z}{2}}\right)\right),</math>

and the quadrusections are

: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{4m} \over (4m)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\cosh{z}+\cos{z}\right)</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{4m+1} \over (4m+1)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\sinh{z}+\sin{z}\right)</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{4m+2} \over (4m+2)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\cosh{z}-\cos{z}\right)</math>
: <math>\sum_{m=0}^\infty {z^{4m+3} \over (4m+3)!} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\sinh{z}-\sin{z}\right).</math>

===Binomial theorem===
Multisection of a [[binomial expansion]]

: <math>(1+x)^n = {n\choose 0} x^0 + {n\choose 1} x + {n\choose 2} x^2 + \cdots</math>

at ''x'' = 1 gives the following identity for the sum of [[binomial coefficients]] with step ''q'':

: <math>{n\choose p} + {n\choose p+q} + {n\choose p+2q} + \cdots = \frac{1}{q}\cdot \sum_{k=0}^{q-1} \left(2 \cos\frac{\pi k}{q}\right )^n\cdot \cos \frac{\pi(n-2p)k}{q}.</math>

pages.title: Shuffle algebra
pages.text:
In mathematics, a '''shuffle algebra''' is a [[Hopf algebra]] with a basis corresponding to words on some set, whose product is given by the '''shuffle product''' ''X'' ⧢ ''Y'' of two words ''X'', ''Y'': the sum of all ways of interlacing them.  The interlacing is given by the [[riffle shuffle permutation]].

The shuffle algebra on a finite set is the graded dual of the [[universal enveloping algebra]] of the [[free Lie algebra]] on the set.

Over the rational numbers, the shuffle algebra is isomorphic to the [[polynomial algebra]] in the [[Lyndon word]]s.

==Shuffle product==
The shuffle product of words of lengths ''m'' and ''n'' is a sum over the {{sfrac|(''m''+''n'')!|''m''!''n''!}} ways of interleaving the two words, as shown in the following examples:
:''ab'' ⧢ ''xy'' = ''abxy'' + ''axby'' + ''xaby'' + ''axyb'' + ''xayb'' + ''xyab''
:''aaa'' ⧢ ''aa'' = 10''aaaaa''

It may be defined inductively by<ref>Lothaire (1997) pp.101,126</ref>
:''u'' ⧢ ε = ε ⧢ ''u'' = ''u''
:''ua'' ⧢ ''vb'' = (''u'' ⧢ ''vb'')''a'' + (''ua'' ⧢ ''v'')''b''
where ε is the [[empty string|empty word]], ''a'' and ''b'' are single elements, and ''u'' and ''v'' are arbitrary words.

The shuffle product was introduced by {{harvtxt|Eilenberg|Mac Lane|1953}}. The name "shuffle product" refers to the fact that the product can be thought of as a sum over all ways of [[riffle shuffle|riffle shuffling]] two words together: this is the [[riffle shuffle permutation]].  The product is [[Commutative property|commutative]] and [[Associative property|associative]].<ref name=L126>Lothaire (1997) p.126</ref>

The shuffle product of two words in some alphabet is often denoted by the '''shuffle product symbol''' ⧢ ([[Unicode]] character U+29E2 {{sc|shuffle product}}, derived from the [[Cyrillic]] letter {{angbr|ш}} [[Sha (Cyrillic)|sha]]).

==Infiltration product==
The closely related '''infiltration product''' was introduced by {{harvtxt|Chen|Fox|Lyndon|1958}}.  It is defined inductively on words over an alphabet ''A'' by

:''fa'' ↑ ''ga'' = (''f'' ↑ ''ga'')''a'' + (''fa'' ↑ ''g'')''a'' + (''f'' ↑ ''g'')''a''
:''fa'' ↑ ''gb'' = (''f'' ↑ ''gb'')''a'' + (''fa'' ↑ ''g'')''b''

For example:
:''ab'' ↑ ''ab'' = ''ab'' + 2''aab'' + 2''abb'' + 4 ''aabb'' + 2''abab''
:''ab'' ↑ ''ba'' = ''aba'' + ''bab'' + ''abab'' + 2''abba'' + 2''baab'' + ''baba''

The infiltration product is also commutative and associative.<ref name=L128>Lothaire (1997) p.128</ref>

pages.title: Smooth algebra
pages.text:
In [[algebra]], a commutative ''k''-algebra ''A'' is said to be '''0-smooth''' if it satisfies the following lifting property: given a ''k''-algebra ''C'', an ideal ''N'' of ''C'' whose square is zero and a ''k''-algebra map  <math>u: A \to C/N</math>, there exists a ''k''-algebra map <math>v: A \to C</math> such that ''u'' is ''v'' followed by the canonical map. If there exists at most one such lifting ''v'', then ''A'' is said to be '''0-unramified''' (or '''0-neat'''). ''A'' is said to be '''0-étale''' if it is '''0-smooth''' and '''0-unramified'''.

A finitely generated ''k''-algebra ''A'' is 0-smooth over ''k'' if and only if Spec ''A'' is a [[smooth scheme]] over ''k''.

A [[separable extension|separable]] algebraic field extension ''L'' of ''k'' is 0-étale over ''k''.<ref>{{harvnb|Matsumura|1986|loc=Theorem 25.3}}</ref> The formal power series ring <math>k[\![t_1, \ldots, t_n]\!]</math> is 0-smooth only when <math>\operatorname{char}k = p > 0</math> and <math>[k: k^p] < \infty</math> (i.e., ''k'' has a finite [[p-basis|''p''-basis]].)<ref>{{harvnb|Matsumura|1986|loc=pg. 215}}</ref>

== ''I''-smooth ==
Let ''B'' be an ''A''-algebra and suppose ''B'' is given the ''I''-adic topology, ''I'' an ideal of ''B''. We say ''B'' is '''''I''-smooth over ''A''''' if it satisfies the lifting property: given an ''A''-algebra ''C'', an ideal ''N'' of ''C'' whose square is zero and an ''A''-algebra map  <math>u: B \to C/N</math> that is continuous when <math>C/N</math> is given the discrete topology, there exists an ''A''-algebra map <math>v: B \to C</math> such that ''u'' is ''v'' followed by the canonical map. As before, if there exists at most one such lift ''v'', then ''B'' is said to be '''''I''-unramified over ''A''''' (or '''''I''-neat'''). ''B'' is said to be '''''I''-étale''' if it is '''''I''-smooth''' and '''''I''-unramified'''. If ''I'' is the zero ideal and ''A'' is a field, these notions coincide with 0-smooth etc. as defined above.

A standard example is this: let ''A'' be a ring, <math>B = A[\![t_1, \ldots, t_n]\!]</math> and <math>I = (t_1, \ldots, t_n).</math> Then ''B'' is ''I''-smooth over ''A''.

Let ''A'' be a noetherian local ''k''-algebra with maximal ideal <math>\mathfrak{m}</math>. Then ''A'' is <math>\mathfrak{m}</math>-smooth over ''k'' if and only if <math>A \otimes_k k'</math> is a regular ring for any finite extension field <math>k'</math> of ''k''.<ref>{{harvnb|Matsumura|1986|loc=Theorem 28.7}}</ref>

pages.title: Spherical design
pages.text:
A '''spherical design''', part of [[combinatorial design]] theory in [[mathematics]], is a finite set of ''N'' points on the ''d''-dimensional unit [[n-sphere|''d''-sphere]] ''S<sup>d</sup>'' such that the average value of any polynomial ''f'' of degree ''t'' or less on the set equals the average value of ''f'' on the whole sphere (that is, the integral of ''f'' over ''S<sup>d</sup>'' divided by the area or [[Measure (mathematics)|measure]] of ''S<sup>d</sup>'').  Such a set is often called a '''spherical''' ''t''-'''design''' to indicate the value of ''t'', which is a fundamental parameter.

Spherical designs can be of value in [[approximation theory]], in [[statistics]] for [[experimental design]] (being usable to construct [[rotatable design]]s), in [[combinatorics]], and in [[geometry]].  The main problem is to find examples, given ''d'' and ''t'', that are not too large; however, such examples may be hard to come by.
Spherical t-designs have also recently been appropriated in [[quantum mechanics]] in the form of [[quantum t-designs]] with various applications to [[quantum information theory]], [[quantum computing]] and [[POVM]]s.

The concept of a spherical design is due to Delsarte, Goethals, and Seidel (1977). 

== Spherical designs in the circle ==

The existence and structure of spherical designs with ''d'' = 1 (that is, in a circle) were studied in depth by Hong (1982).

== Spherical designs in any dimension ==

Shortly thereafter, Seymour and Zaslavsky (1984) proved that such designs exist of all sufficiently large sizes; that is, given positive integers ''n'' and ''t'', there is a number ''N''(''d'',''t'') such that for every ''N'' ≥ ''N''(''d'',''t'') there exists a spherical ''t''-design of ''N'' points in dimension ''d''.  However, their proof gave no idea of how big ''N''(''d'',''t'') is.  Good estimates for that were found later on.  Besides these "large" sizes, there are many sporadic small spherical designs; many of them are related to finite [[Group action (mathematics)|group action]]s on the sphere and are of great interest in themselves.

Recently, Bondarenko, Radchenko, and Viazovska obtained the asymptotic upper bound
<math> N(d,t)<C_d t^d</math> for all positive integers ''d'' and ''t''.  This is optimal except that the value of ''C<sub>d</sub>'' is unknown.

== 2-dimensional spherical design ==
{{main | geodesic grid }}

Spherical designs with ''d'' = 2 (that is, on the surface of a sphere) ...

One application of spherical designs is for whole-sphere data collection.
Spherical t-designs meet the "accurately approximate integrals by sums" criteria for "good" pixelizations of the sphere.<ref>
[http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/1538-4357/470/2/L81/5407.text.html "An Icosahedron-based Method for Pixelizing the Celestial Sphere"]
by Max Tegmark 1996
</ref>

==See also==
* [[Thomson problem]]

==External links==
* Spherical t-designs for different values of  ''N'' and ''t'' can be found precomputed at [http://neilsloane.com/sphdesigns/ Neil Sloane's website].

pages.title: Spherically complete field
pages.text:
In mathematics, a [[Field (mathematics)|field]] ''K'' with an [[Absolute value#Fields|absolute value]] is called '''spherically complete''' if the [[Intersection (set theory)|intersection]] of every [[decreasing sequence]] of [[Ball (mathematics)|balls]] (in the sense of the metric induced by the absolute value) is nonempty:
:<math>B_1\supseteq B_2\supseteq \cdots \Rightarrow\bigcap_{n\in {\mathbf N}} B_n\neq \empty.</math>
The definition can be adapted also to a field ''K'' with a [[Valuation (algebra)|valuation]] ''v'' taking values in an arbitrary ordered abelian group: (''K'',''v'') is spherically complete if every collection of balls that is totally ordered by inclusion has a nonempty intersection.

Spherically complete fields are important in [[archimedean property|nonarchimedean]] [[functional analysis]], since many results analogous to theorems of classical functional analysis require the base field to be spherically complete.

==Examples==
*Any [[locally compact]] field is spherically complete. This includes, in particular, the fields '''Q'''<sub>''p''</sub> of [[p-adic number]]s, and any of their finite extensions.
*On the other hand, '''C'''<sub>''p''</sub>, the [[complete metric space|completion]] of the [[algebraic closure]] of '''Q'''<sub>''p''</sub>, is not spherically complete.<ref>Robert, [https://books.google.de/books?id=H6sq_x2-DgoC&PA143 p. 143]</ref>
*Any field of [[Hahn series]] is spherically complete.

pages.title: Square (algebra)
pages.text: {{Redirect|²|typography of superscripts|subscript and superscript}} {{no footnotes|date=August 2015}} [[Image:Five Squared.svg|thumb|right|168px|{{math|5⋅5}}, or {{math|52}} (5 squared), can be shown graphically using a [[square]]. Each block represents one unit, {{math|1⋅1}}, and the entire square represents {{math|5⋅5}}, or the area of the square.]] In [[mathematics]], a '''square''' is the result of [[multiplication|multiplying]] a [[number]] by itself. The verb "to square" is used to denote this operation. Squaring is the same as [[exponentiation|raising to]] the power [[2 (number)|2]], and is denoted by a [[superscript]] 2; for instance, the square of 3 may be written as 32, which is the number 9. In some cases when superscripts are not available, as for instance in [[programming language]]s or [[plain text]] files, the notations ''x''^2 or ''x''**2 may be used in place of ''x''2. The adjective which corresponds to squaring is ''[[wikt:quadratic|quadratic]]''. The square of an [[integer]] may also be called a [[square number]] or a perfect square. In [[algebra]], the operation of squaring is often generalized to [[polynomial]]s, other [[expression (mathematics)|expressions]], or values in systems of mathematical values other than the numbers. For instance, the square of the [[linear function (calculus)|linear polynomial]] {{math|''x'' + 1}} is the [[quadratic polynomial]] {{math|1=(''x''+1)2 = ''x''2 + 2''x'' + 1}}. One of the important properties of squaring, for numbers as well as in many other mathematical systems, is that (for all numbers {{mvar|x}}), the square of {{mvar|x}} is the same as the square of its [[additive inverse]] {{math|−''x''}}. That is, the square function satisfies the identity {{math|1=''x''2 = (−''x'')2}}. This can also be expressed by saying that the square function is an [[even function]]. == In real numbers == [[Image:Parabola2.svg|thumb|240px|The graph of the square function {{math|1=''y'' = ''x''2}} is a [[parabola]].]] The squaring operation defines a [[real function]] called the '''{{vanchor|square function}}''' or the '''{{vanchor|squaring function}}'''. Its [[domain of a function|domain]] is the whole [[real line]], and its [[image (function)|image]] is the set of nonnegative real numbers. The square function preserves the order of positive numbers: larger numbers have larger squares. In other words, the square is a [[monotonic function]] on the interval {{closed-open|0, +∞}}. On the negative numbers, numbers with greater absolute value have greater squares, so the square is a monotonically decreasing function on {{open-closed|−∞,0}}. Hence, [[zero]] is the (global) [[minimum]] of the square function. The square {{math|''x''2}} of a number {{math|''x''}} is less than {{mvar|x}} (that is {{math|''x''2 < ''x''}}) if and only if {{math|0 < ''x'' < 1}}, that is, if {{mvar|x}} belongs to the [[open interval]] {{open-open|0,1}}. This implies that the square of an integer is never less than the original number {{mvar|x}}. Every positive [[real number]] is the square of exactly two numbers, one of which is strictly positive and the other of which is strictly negative. Zero is the square of only one number, itself. For this reason, it is possible to define the [[square root]] function, which associates with a non-negative real number the non-negative number whose square is the original number. No square root can be taken of a negative number within the system of [[real number]]s, because squares of all real numbers are [[non-negative]]. The lack of real square roots for the negative numbers can be used to expand the real number system to the [[complex number]]s, by postulating the [[imaginary unit]] {{mvar|i}}, which is one of the square roots of −1. The property "every non-negative real number is a square" has been generalized to the notion of a [[real closed field]], which is an [[ordered field]] such that every non-negative element is a square and every polynomial of odd degree has a root. The real closed fields cannot be distinguished from the field of real numbers by their algebraic properties: every property of the real numbers, which may be expressed in [[first-order logic]] (that is expressed by a formula in which the variables that are quantified by ∀ or ∃ represent elements, not sets), is true for every real closed field, and conversely every property of the first-order logic, which is true for a specific real closed field is also true for the real numbers. == In geometry == There are several major uses of the square function in geometry. The name of the square function shows its importance in the definition of the [[area]]: it comes from the fact that the area of a [[square]] with sides of length  {{mvar|l}} is equal to {{math|''l''2}}. The area depends quadratically on the size: the area of a shape {{mvar|n}} times larger is {{math|''n''2}} times greater. This holds for areas in three dimensions as well as in the plane: for instance, the surface area of a [[sphere]] is proportional to the square of its radius, a fact that is manifested physically by the [[inverse-square law]] describing how the strength of physical forces such as gravity varies according to distance. {{anchor|r²}}[[Image:Zonenplatte Cosinus.png|thumb|right|Fresnel's [[zone plate]]s have rings with [[arithmetic progression|equally spaced]] squared distances to the center]] The square function is related to [[distance]] through the [[Pythagorean theorem]] and its generalization, the [[parallelogram law]]. [[Euclidean geometry|Euclidean]] distance is not a [[smooth function]]: the [[graph of a function of two variables|three-dimensional graph]] of distance from a fixed point forms a [[cone]], with a non-smooth point at the tip of the cone. However, the square of the distance (denoted {{math|''d''2}} or {{math|''r''2}}), which has a [[paraboloid]] as its graph, is a smooth and [[analytic function]]. The [[dot product]] of a [[Euclidean vector]] with itself is equal to the square of its length: {{math|1='''v'''⋅'''v''' = v2}}. This is further generalised to [[quadratic form]]s in [[linear space]]s. The [[inertia tensor]] in [[mechanics]] is an example of a quadratic form. It demonstrates a quadratic relation of the [[moment of inertia]] to the size ([[length]]). There are infinitely many [[Pythagorean triple]]s, sets of three positive integers such that the sum of the squares of the first two equals the square of the third. Each of these triples gives the integer sides of a right triangle. ==In abstract algebra and number theory== The square function is defined in any [[field (mathematics)|field]] or [[ring (mathematics)|ring]]. An element in the image of this function is called a ''square'', and the inverse images of a square are called ''[[square root]]s''. The notion of squaring is particularly important in the [[finite field]]s '''Z'''/''p'''''Z''' formed by the numbers modulo an odd [[prime number]] {{mvar|p}}. A non-zero element of this field is called a [[quadratic residue]] if it is a square in '''Z'''/''p'''''Z''', and otherwise, it is called a quadratic non-residue. Zero, while a square, is not considered to be a quadratic residue. Every finite field of this type has exactly {{math|(''p'' − 1)/2}} quadratic residues and exactly {{math|(''p'' − 1)/2}} quadratic non-residues. The quadratic residues form a [[group (mathematics)|group]] under multiplication. The properties of quadratic residues are widely used in [[number theory]]. More generally, in rings, the square function may have different properties that are sometimes used to classify rings. Zero may be the square of some non-zero elements. A [[commutative ring]] such that the square of a non zero element is never zero is called a [[reduced ring]]. More generally, in a commutative ring, a [[radical ideal]] is an ideal {{mvar|I}} such that x^2 \in I implies x \in I. Both notions are important in [[algebraic geometry]], because of [[Hilbert's Nullstellensatz]]. An element of a ring that is equal to its own square is called an [[idempotent]]. In any ring, 0 and 1 are idempotents. {{anchor|integral domains}}There are no other idempotents in fields and more generally in [[integral domain]]s. However, the ring of the integers [[modular arithmetic|modulo]] {{mvar|n}} has [[power of two|{{math|2''k''}}]] idempotents, where {{mvar|k}} is the number of distinct [[integer factorization|prime factors]] of {{mvar|n}}. A commutative ring in which every element is equal to its square (every element is idempotent) is called a [[Boolean ring]]; an example from [[computer science]] is the ring whose elements are [[binary number]]s, with [[Bitwise operation|bitwise AND]] as the multiplication operation and bitwise XOR as the addition operation. In a [[supercommutative algebra]] ([[away from 2]]), the square of any ''odd'' element equals to zero. If ''A'' is a [[commutative property|commutative]] [[semigroup]], then one has :\forall x, y \isin A \quad (xy)^2 = xy xy = xx yy = x^2 y^2 . In the language of [[quadratic form]]s, this equality says that the square function is a "form permitting composition". In fact, the square function is the foundation upon which other quadratic forms are constructed which also permit composition. The procedure was introduced by [[L. E. Dickson]] to produce the [[octonion]]s out of [[quaternion]]s by doubling. The doubling method was formalized by [[A. A. Albert]] who started with the [[real number]] [[field (mathematics)|field]] ℝ and the square function, doubling it to obtain the [[complex number]] field with quadratic form x2 + y2, and then doubling again to obtain quaternions. The doubling procedure is called the [[Cayley–Dickson process]] and the structures produced are [[composition algebra]]s. The square function can be used with ℂ as the start for another use of the Cayley–Dickson process leading to bicomplex, biquaternion, and bioctonion composition algebras. ==In complex numbers and related algebras over the reals== {{anchor|In complex analysis}} {{see also|Exponentiation #Powers of complex numbers}} The [[complex numbers|complex]] square function {{math|''z''2}} is a twofold cover of the [[complex plane]], such that each non-zero complex number has exactly two square roots. This map is related to [[parabolic coordinates]]. == Other uses == Squares are ubiquitous in algebra, more generally, in almost every branch of mathematics, and also in [[physics]] where many [[unit of measurement|units]] are defined using squares and [[multiplicative inverse|inverse]] squares: see [[#Related physical quantities|below]]. [[Least squares]] is the standard method used with [[overdetermined system]]s. Squaring is used in [[statistics]] and [[probability theory]] in determining the [[standard deviation]] of a set of values, or a [[random variable]]. The deviation of each value {{mvar|xi}} from the [[mean]] \overline{x} of the set is defined as the difference x_i - \overline{x}. These deviations are squared, then a mean is taken of the new set of numbers (each of which is positive). This mean is the [[variance]], and its square root is the standard deviation. In [[finance]], the [[volatility (finance)|volatility]] of a financial instrument is the standard deviation of its values. ==See also== * [[Exponentiation by squaring]] * [[Polynomial SOS]], the representation of a non-negative polynomial as the sum of squares of polynomials * [[Hilbert's seventeenth problem]], for the representation of [[positive polynomial]]s as a sum of squares of [[rational function]]s * [[Square-free polynomial]] * [[Cube (algebra)]] * [[Metric tensor]] * [[Quadratic equation]] * [[Polynomial ring]] * [[Sums of squares (disambiguation)|Sums of squares]] (disambiguation page with various relevant links) === Related identities === ; Algebraic (need a [[commutative ring]]): * [[Difference of two squares]] * [[Brahmagupta–Fibonacci identity]], related to complex numbers [[#.7Cz.7C²|in the sense discussed above]] * [[Euler's four-square identity]], related to [[quaternion]]s in the same way * [[Degen's eight-square identity]], related to [[octonion]]s in the same way * [[Lagrange's identity]] ; Other * [[Pythagorean trigonometric identity]] * [[Parseval's identity]] === Related physical quantities === * [[acceleration]], length per square time * [[cross section (physics)]], an area-dimensioned quantity * [[coupling constant]] (has square charge in the denominator, and may be expressed with square distance in the numerator) * [[kinetic energy]] (quadratic dependence on velocity) * [[specific energy]], a (square velocity)-dimensioned quantity == Footnotes == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Marshall, Murray Positive polynomials and sums of squares. Mathematical Surveys and Monographs, 146. American Mathematical Society, Providence, RI, 2008. xii+187 pp. {{isbn|978-0-8218-4402-1}}, {{isbn|0-8218-4402-4}} * {{cite book | title=Squares | volume=171 | series=London Mathematical Society Lecture Note Series | first=A. R. | last=Rajwade | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] | year=1993 | isbn=0-521-42668-5 | zbl=0785.11022 }} [[Category:Algebra]] [[Category:Elementary arithmetic]] [[Category:Exponentials|2]] [[Category:Squares in number theory]] [[Category:Unary operations]]

pages.title: Stereotype algebra
pages.text:
In [[functional analysis]] and related areas of [[mathematics]], '''stereotype algebras''' are [[topological algebra]]s defined as [[stereotype space]]s with a (unital and associative) multiplication satisfying the condition of separate uniform continuity on compact sets.

== Definition ==
There are two equivalent ways to define stereotype algebra. 

* '''An abstract definition''': a (projective<ref name=projectivealgebra>There is another notion, an '''injective stereotype algebra''', which is defined as a [[monoid (category theory)|monoid]] in the [[Stereotype space#Category of stereotype spaces|monoidal category ('''Ste''',<math>\odot</math>,<math>{\mathbb C}</math>)]] of stereotype spaces with the dual tensor product, <math>\odot</math>. The class of these algebras is much narrower.</ref>) '''stereotype algebra'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=271}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2005}} is a [[monoid (category theory)|monoid]] in the [[Stereotype space#Category of stereotype spaces|monoidal category ('''Ste''',<math>\circledast</math>,<math>{\mathbb C}</math>)]] of stereotype spaces with the tensor product <math>\circledast</math>.

* '''An analytic definition''': let <math>A</math> be a [[stereotype space]] (over the field <math>\mathbb C</math> of complex numbers<ref>...or the field <math>\mathbb R</math> of real numbers</ref>) and suppose it is endowed with a bilinear operation <math>(x,y)\in A\times A\mapsto x\cdot y\in A</math> that turns <math>A</math> into a [[unital algebra|unital]] and [[associative algebra]] (over the field <math>\mathbb C</math>). Then <math>A</math> is called a (projective) '''stereotype algebra'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=271}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=483}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=147}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017|p=594}} if the multiplication <math>(x,y)\in A\times A\to A</math> is a [[Stereotype space#Universality of tensor product|continuous bilinear map in the stereotype sense]], i.e. if for each [[compact set]] <math>S\subseteq A</math> and for each neighbourhood of zero <math>U\subseteq A</math> there is a neighbourhood of zero <math>V\subseteq A</math> such that <math>S\cdot V\subseteq U\quad \&\quad V\cdot S\subseteq U.
</math><ref>The requirement on <math>A</math> in the analytic definition of stereotype algebra can be equivalently expressed as follows: for each [[compact set]] <math>S\subseteq A</math> and for each [[Net (mathematics)|net]] <math>y_i</math> tending to zero in <math>A</math>,
<math>
y_i\overset{A}{\underset{i\to\infty}{\longrightarrow}}0
</math> 
the nets <math>x\cdot y_i</math> and <math>y_i\cdot x</math> tend to zero in <math>A</math> uniformly on <math>x\in S</math>:
<math>
x\cdot y_i\overset{A}{\underset{x\in S}{\underset{i\to\infty}{\rightrightarrows}}}0
\quad \&\quad y_i\cdot x\overset{A}{\underset{x\in S}{\underset{i\to\infty}{\rightrightarrows}}}0.
</math></ref>

A ''morphism of stereotype algebras'' <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> is a continuous unital<ref>A homomorphism <math>\varphi:A\to B</math> is said to be ''unital'' if it preserves unit: <math>\varphi(1_A)=1_B</math>.</ref> homomorphism <math>\varphi:A\to B</math>.

Stereotype algebras form a subclass in the class of ''separately continuous'' [[topological algebra]]s.

== Examples ==

:1. All [[Fréchet algebra]]s are stereotype. In particular, all [[Banach algebra]]s are stereotype.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=272}}  
:2. For each [[stereotype space]] <math>X</math> the stereotype space of operators <math>X\oslash X</math>, <math>\varphi:X\to X</math>, is a stereotype algebra with respect to the operation of composition.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=272}}
:3. The main examples of ''functional algebras''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=272}} in Analysis and Geometry are stereotype algebras: 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal C}(M)</math> of [[continuous function]]s on a [[paracompact space|paracompact]] [[locally compact topological space]] <math>M</math> with the topology of uniform convergence on compact sets <math>T\subseteq M</math>, 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal E}(M)</math> of [[smooth function]]s on a [[smooth manifold]] <math>M</math> with the topology of uniform convergence with all derivatives on compact sets <math>T\subseteq M</math>, 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal O}(M)</math> of [[holomorphic function]]s on a [[Stein manifold]] <math>M</math> with the topology of uniform convergence on compact sets <math>T\subseteq M</math>, 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal P}(M)</math> of [[polynomials]] (regular functions) on an [[affine algebraic variety]] <math>M</math> with the strongest locally convex topology. 
:4. [[Group algebra#Stereotype group algebras|Stereotype group algebras]]. In the case when the space <math>M</math> in the previous examples has a structure of a [[topological group]], the [[Stereotype space#Definition|dual stereotype spaces]] to the functional algebras on <math>M</math> are stereotype algebras with respect to the operation of [[convolution#Convolution of measures|convolution]]:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=272}} 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal C}^\star(G)</math> of [[Radon measure]]s with compact support on a [[locally compact group]] <math>G</math>,<ref>If <math>G</math> is an infinite locally compact group then the algebra <math>{\mathcal C}^\star(G)</math> of measures on <math>G</math> is not a [[Fréchet algebra]]. In the case when <math>G</math> is compact, <math>{\mathcal C}^\star(G)</math> is a [[Smith space]]. If <math>G</math> is <math>\sigma</math>-compact, then <math>{\mathcal C}^\star(G)</math> is a [[Brauner space]].</ref> 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal E}^\star(G)</math> of [[distribution (mathematics)|distribution]]s with compact support on a [[real Lie group]] <math>G</math>, 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal O}^\star(G)</math> of holomorphic functionals on a Stein group<ref name=Stein-group>A ''Stein group'' is a [[complex Lie group]] <math>G</math> which is a [[Stein manifold]].</ref> <math>G</math>, 
::* the algebra <math>{\mathcal P}^\star(G)</math> of currents on an [[affine algebraic group]] <math>G</math>.
:In contrast to the other models of group algebras in functional analysis, the stereotype group algebras possess the [[Group algebra#Stereotype group algebras|universal property]]<ref>I.e. the homomorphisms of stereotype algebras <math>{\mathcal C}^\star(G)\to A</math> are in one-to-one correspondence with the continuous representations <math>G\to A</math> of the group <math>G</math>, and the same is true for the algebras <math>{\mathcal E}^\star(G)</math>, <math>{\mathcal O}^\star(G)</math> and <math>{\mathcal P}^\star(G)</math> with the smooth, holomorphic and polynomial representations of the corresponding groups.</ref>{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=275}} and the structure of [[Hopf algebra]]{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=507}}.

== Stereotype modules ==

A stereotype space <math>X</math> is called a ''left stereotype module'' over a stereotype algebra <math>A</math>, if a bilinear operation <math>(a,x)\in A\times X\mapsto a\cdot x\in X</math> is defined that turns <math>X</math> into a left [[module (mathematics)|module]] over <math>A</math>, and this operation is a [[Stereotype space#Universality of tensor product|continuous bilinear map in the stereotype sense]]: for each [[compact set]] <math>S\subseteq A</math> and for each neighbourhood of zero <math>U\subseteq X</math> there is a neighbourhood of zero <math>V\subseteq X</math> such that 

<math>
S\cdot V\subseteq U,
</math>

and at the same time for each [[compact set]] <math>T\subseteq X</math> and for each neighbourhood of zero <math>U\subseteq X</math> there is a neighbourhood of zero <math>W\subseteq A</math> such that 

<math>
W\cdot T\subseteq U.
</math>

The notion of a ''right stereotype module'' over a stereotype algebra <math>A</math> is defined by analogy.

The theory of stereotype algebras allows to simplify the formulations in the theory of [[topological algebra]]s and to bring this field closer to [[abstract algebra]]. The following two results (which do not hold for general jointly or separately continuous algebras) are typical illustrations.<ref>Other illustrations are the already mentioned [[Group algebra#Stereotype group algebras|universality property for the stereotype group algebras]]{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=275}} and the structure of [[Hopf algebra]] on them{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=507}}.
</ref>

'''Theorem'''.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=283}} ''A stereotype space <math>X</math> with a structure of left (right) module over a stereotype algebra <math>A</math> is a stereotype module over <math>A</math> if and only if the operation of multiplication <math>(a,x)\in A\times X\mapsto a\cdot x\in X</math> (respectively, <math>(x,a)\in X\times A\mapsto x\cdot a\in X</math>) defines a continuous map (a representation) <math>A\to X\oslash X</math>.''<ref>Here <math>X\oslash X</math> is the [[Stereotype space#Ste as a *-autonomous category|stereotype space of operators <math>\varphi:X\to X</math>]].</ref>

'''Theorem'''.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=289}} ''For each stereotype algebra <math>A</math> the categories <sub><math>A</math></sub>'''Ste''' and '''Ste'''<sub><math>A</math></sub> of left and right stereotype modules over <math>A</math> are [[Enriched category|enriched categories]] over the [[Stereotype space#Ste as a *-autonomous category|monoidal category ('''Ste''',<math>\circledast</math>,<math>{\mathbb C}</math>)]] of stereotype spaces.''

== Applications ==

The notion of stereotype algebra is used in the generalizations{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}} of the [[Pontryagin  duality]] theory to the classes of non-commutative groups based on the notion of [[Envelope (category theory)|envelope]]: the holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous envelopes of stereotype algebras lead respectively to the constructions of the holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous dualities in ''big geometric disciplines'' – [[complex geometry]], [[differential geometry]], and [[topology]] – for certain classes of (not necessarily commutative) topological groups considered in these disciplines ([[affine algebraic group]]s, and some classes of [[Lie group]]s and Moore groups).{{sfn|Akbarov|2009}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}}{{sfn|Kuznetsova|2013}}

pages.title: Stereotype space
pages.text:
In [[functional analysis]] and related areas of [[mathematics]], '''stereotype spaces''' are [[topological vector space]]s defined by a special variant of [[Reflexive space|reflexivity]] condition. They form a class of spaces with a series of remarkable properties, in particular, this class is very wide (for instance, it contains all [[Fréchet space]]s and thus, all [[Banach space]]s), it consists of spaces satisfying a natural condition of completeness, and it forms a [[*-autonomous category]] with the standard analytical tools for constructing new spaces, like taking dual spaces, spaces of operators, tensor products, and in addition, immediate subspaces, immediate quotient spaces, products and coproducts, limits and colimits, etc. 
[[File:Stereotype spaces -2 .jpg|thumb|Mutual embeddings of the main classes of locally convex spaces.]]

==Definition==

A '''stereotype space'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=219}} is a [[topological vector space]] <math>X</math> over the field <math>\mathbb{C}</math> of complex numbers<ref>...or over the field <math>\mathbb{R}</math> of real numbers, with the similar definition.</ref> such that the natural map into the second dual space

:<math> i:X\to X^{\star\star},\quad i(x)(f)=f(x),\quad x\in X,\quad f\in X^\star </math>

is an isomorphism of topological vector spaces (i.e. a [[Linear map|linear]] and a [[Homeomorphism|homeomorphic]] map). Here the ''dual space'' <math> X^\star</math> is defined as the space of all linear continuous functionals <math>f:X\to\mathbb{C}</math> endowed with the topology of uniform convergence on [[Totally bounded space#Definitions in other contexts|totally bounded set]]s in <math>X</math>, and the ''second dual space'' <math> X^{\star\star}</math> is the space dual to <math> X^{\star}</math> in the same sense.

The following criterion holds:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=219, 220}} a topological vector space <math>X</math> is stereotype if and only if it is [[Locally convex space|locally convex]] and satisfies the following two conditions:

:* ''pseudocompleteness'': each [[Totally bounded set|totally bounded]] [[Net (mathematics)#Cauchy nets|Cauchy net]] in <math>X</math> converges,

:* ''pseudosaturateness'': each closed convex balanced ''capacious''<ref>A set <math>D\subseteq X</math> is said to be ''capacious'' if for each [[Totally bounded set|totally bounded]] set <math>A\subseteq X</math> there is a finite set <math>F\subseteq X</math> such that <math>A\subseteq D+F</math>.</ref> set <math>D</math> in <math>X</math> is a neighborhood of zero in <math>X</math>.

The property of being pseudocomplete is a weakening of the usual notion of completeness, while the property of being pseudosaturated is a weakening of the notion of [[Barreled space|barreledness]] of a topological vector space.

==Examples==
The class '''Ste''' of stereotype spaces is extremely wide, so that it will not be a serious exaggeration to say that all topological vector spaces really used in analysis are stereotype.{{sfn|Akbarov|2005}} Each pseudocomplete [[barreled space]] <math>X</math> (in particular, each [[Banach space]] and each [[Fréchet space]]) is stereotype{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=Example 4.3|p=220}}. Its dual space <math>X^\star</math> (which is not barreled, unless <math>X</math> is a [[Montel space]]) is stereotype as well<ref>Of course, this is a general fact: if <math>X</math> is stereotype then <math>X^\star</math> is also stereotype.</ref>. There exist stereotype spaces which are not [[Mackey space]]s{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=Example 4.8|p=221}}.

Some simple connections between the properties of a stereotype space <math>X</math> and those of its dual space <math>X^\star</math> are expressed in the following list of regularities:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=221|loc=Theorem 4.11}}

:* <math>X</math> is a [[normed space]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math>  <math>X</math> is a [[Banach space]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X^\star</math> is a [[Smith space]];

:* <math>X</math> is [[Metrization theorem|metrizable]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math>  <math>X</math> is a [[Fréchet space]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math>  <math>X^\star</math> is a [[Brauner space]];

:* <math>X</math> is [[barreled space|barreled]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math>  <math>X^\star</math> has the [[Heine-Borel theorem#In the theory of topological vector spaces|Heine-Borel property]];

:* <math>X</math> is [[Barrelled space#Quasi-barrelled spaces|quasi-barreled]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> if a set <math>T</math> is absorbed by each barrel, then <math>T</math> is totally bounded;

:* <math>X</math> is a [[Mackey space]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> every <math>X</math>-weakly compact set is compact;

:* <math>X</math> is a [[Montel space]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X</math> is barreled and has the [[Heine-Borel theorem#In the theory of topological vector spaces|Heine-Borel property]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X^\star</math>  is a Montel space;

:* <math>X</math> is a space with a [[weak topology]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> every compact set <math>T</math> is finite-dimensional;

:* <math>X</math> is [[separable space|separable]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> there is a sequence of closed subspaces <math>L_n</math> of finite co-dimension with trivial intersection: <math>\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}L_n=\{0\}</math>.

:* <math>X</math> has the (classical) [[approximation property]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X^\star</math> has the (classical) [[approximation property]];

:* <math>X</math> is [[Uniform space|complete]] <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X^\star</math> is co-complete<ref>A locally convex space  <math>X</math> is called ''co-complete'' if each linear functional <math>f:X\to\mathbb{C}</math> which is continuous on every totally bounded set <math>S\subseteq X</math>, is automatically continuous on the whole space <math>X</math>.</ref>  <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> <math>X^\star</math> is saturated;<ref>A locally convex space <math>X</math> is said to be ''saturated'' if for an absolutely convex set <math>B\subseteq X</math> being a neighbourhood of zero in <math>X</math> is equivalent to the following: for each totally bounded set  <math>S\subseteq X</math> there is a closed neighbourhood of zero <math>U</math> in <math>X</math> such that <math>B\cap S=U</math>.</ref>

:* <math>X</math> is a Pták space<ref>A locally convex space <math>X</math> is called a ''Pták space'', or a ''fully complete space'', if in its dual space  <math>X^\star</math> a subspace <math>Q\subseteq X^\star</math> is <math>X</math>-weakly closed when it has <math>X</math>-weakly closed intersection with the polar <math>U^\circ</math> of each neighbourhood of zero <math>U\subseteq X</math>.</ref> <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> a subspace <math>L</math> is closed if it has the closed intersection <math>L\cap K</math> with each compact set <math>K\subseteq X^\star</math>;

:* <math>X</math> is hypercomplete<ref>A locally convex space <math>X</math> is said to be ''hypercomplete'' if in its dual space <math>X^\star</math> every absolutely convex space <math>Q\subseteq X^\star</math> is <math>X</math>-weakly closed if it  has <math>X</math>-weakly closed intersection with the polar <math>U^\circ</math> of each neighbourhood of zero  <math>U\subseteq X</math>.</ref> <math>\Longleftrightarrow</math> in <math>X^\star</math> an absolutely convex set  <math>B</math> is closed if it has the closed intersection <math>B\cap K</math> with each compact set <math>K\subseteq X^\star</math>.

'''Counterexamples:''' 

1. If a metrizable locally convex space <math>X</math> is not complete, then it is not stereotype.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=Example 4.10|p=221}} 

2. If <math>X</math> is an infinite dimensional Banach  space, and <math>Y=X'_\sigma</math> is its dual space (of linear continuous functionals <math>f:X\to{\mathbb C}</math>) considered with the <math>X</math>-weak topology, then <math>Y</math> is not stereotype.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=Example 4.9|p=221}}

==History==

The first results on this type of reflexivity of topological vector spaces were obtained by M. F. Smith{{sfn|Smith|1952}}{{sfn|Onishchik|1984}} in 1952. Further investigations were conducted by B. S. Brudovskii,
{{sfn|Brudovski|1967}} W. C. Waterhouse,{{sfn|Waterhouse|1968}} K. Brauner,{{sfn|Brauner|1973}} S. S. Akbarov,{{sfn|Akbarov|2003}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2009}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}} and E. T. Shavgulidze.{{sfn|Akbarov|Shavgulidze|2003}} The term "stereotype space" was introduced by S. S. Akbarov in 1995{{sfn|Akbarov|1995}}. The main properties of the category of stereotype spaces were described by S. S. Akbarov in his series of works of 1995-2017.

==Pseudocompletion and pseudosaturation==

Each [[locally convex space]] <math>X</math> can be transformed into a stereotype space with the help of two standard operations, pseudocompletion and pseudosaturation, defined by the following two propositions.
[[File:Definition-of-pseudocompletion.jpg|thumb]]
:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=197}} ''For each locally convex space <math>X</math> there exists a pseudocomplete locally convex space <math>X^\triangledown</math> and a linear continuous mapping <math>{\triangledown}_X :X \to X^{\triangledown}</math> such that for every pseudocomplete locally convex space <math>Y</math> and for every linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi:X\to Y</math> there is a unique linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi^\triangledown:X^\triangledown\to Y</math> such that
:<math>\varphi^\triangledown\circ{\triangledown}_X=\varphi </math>.''
The space <math>X^\triangledown</math> is called a ''pseudocompletion'' of the space <math>X</math>. It is unique up to an isomorphism of locally convex spaces. 
[[File:Functoriality-of-pseudocompletion.jpg|thumb]]
For each linear continuous mapping of locally convex spaces <math>\varphi :X\to Y</math> there is a unique linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi^{\triangledown} :X^{\triangledown} \to Y^{\triangledown}</math> such that 
:<math>\triangledown_Y\circ\varphi=\varphi^\triangledown\circ\triangledown_X</math>,
and the correspondence <math>\varphi\mapsto\varphi^{\triangledown}</math> can be defined as a (covariant) [[functor]].

The pseudocompletion <math>X^{\triangledown}</math> can be defined as an [[Envelope (category theory)|envelope]] of the locally convex space <math>X</math> in the class <math>\operatorname{PC}</math> of all pseudocomplete locally convex spaces with respect to the same class <math>\operatorname{PC}</math>:
:<math>X^{\triangledown}=\operatorname{Env}_{\operatorname{PC}}^{\operatorname{PC}} X</math>
One can imagine the pseudocompletion of <math>X</math> as the "nearest to <math>X</math> from the outside" pseudocomplete locally convex space, so that the operation <math>X\mapsto X^\triangledown</math> adds to <math>X</math> some supplementary elements, but does not change the topology of <math>X</math> (like the usual operation of completion).
[[File:Definition-of-pseudosaturation.jpg|thumb]]
:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=200}} ''For each locally convex space <math>X</math> there is a pseudosaturated locally convex space <math>X^\vartriangle</math> and a linear continuous mapping <math>{\vartriangle}_X :X^{\vartriangle} \to X</math> such that for each pseudosaturated locally convex space <math>Y</math> and for each linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi:Y\to X</math> there is a unique linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi^\vartriangle:Y\to X^\vartriangle</math> such that
:<math>{\vartriangle}_X\circ\varphi^\vartriangle=\varphi.</math>''
The space <math>X^\vartriangle</math> is called a ''pseudosaturation'' of the space <math>X</math>. It is unique up to an isomorphism of locally convex spaces.
[[File:Functoriality-of-pseudosaturation.jpg|thumb]]
For each linear continuous mapping of locally convex spaces <math>\varphi :Y\to X</math> there is a unique linear continuous mapping <math>\varphi^{\vartriangle} :Y^{\vartriangle} \to X^{\vartriangle}</math> such that
:<math>\varphi\ \circ\vartriangle_Y=\vartriangle_X\circ\ \varphi^\vartriangle</math>, 
and the correspondence <math>\varphi\mapsto\varphi^{\vartriangle}</math> can be defined as a (covariant) [[functor]].

The pseudosaturation <math>X^{\triangledown}</math> can be defined as a [[Refinement (category theory)|refinement]] of the locally convex space <math>X</math> in the class <math>\operatorname{PS}</math> of all pseudosaturated locally convex spaces with respect to the same class <math>\operatorname{PS}</math>:
:<math>X^{\vartriangle}=\operatorname{Ref}_{\operatorname{PS}}^{\operatorname{PS}} X.</math>
One can imagine the pseudosaturation of <math>X</math> as the "nearest to <math>X</math> from the inside" pseudosaturated locally convex space, so that the operation <math>X\mapsto X^\vartriangle</math> strengthens the topology of <math>X</math>, but does not change the elements of <math>X</math>.

If <math>X</math> is a pseudocomplete locally convex space, then its pseudosaturation <math>X^\vartriangle</math> is stereotype. Dually, if <math>X</math> is a pseudosaturated locally convex space, then its pseudocompletion <math>X^\triangledown</math>  is stereotype. For arbitrary locally convex space <math>X</math> the spaces  <math>X^{\vartriangle\triangledown}</math> and <math>X^{\triangledown\vartriangle}</math> are stereotype.<ref>It is not clear (2017) whether <math>X^{\vartriangle\triangledown}</math> and <math>X^{\triangledown\vartriangle}</math> coincide.</ref>

==Immediate subspaces and immediate quotient spaces==
The idea of subspace (and of quotient space) in stereotype theory leads to more complicated results than in the theory of locally convex spaces.

===Immediate subspaces and envelopes===
The notion of immediate subspace gives a "concrete description" of the abstract notion of [[Monomorphism#Related concepts|''immediate monomorphism'']]<ref>A [[monomorphism]] <math>\mu</math> is said to be ''immediate'' if in each representation <math>\mu=\mu'\circ\varepsilon</math>, where <math>\mu'</math> is a monomorphism and <math>\varepsilon</math> is an [[epimorphism]], the morphism <math>\varepsilon</math> is automatically an [[isomorphism]].</ref>, or, what is equivalent in this situation{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=39}}, [[Monomorphism#Related concepts|strong monomorphism]]<ref>[[File:Diagram-orthogonality-2.jpg|thumb]] A [[monomorphism]] <math>\mu:C\to D</math> is said to be '''strong''', if for any [[epimorphism]] <math>\varepsilon:A\to B</math> and for any morphisms <math>\alpha:A\to C</math>  and <math>\beta:B\to D</math> such that <math>\beta\circ\varepsilon=\mu\circ\alpha</math> there exists a morphism <math>\delta:B\to C</math>, such that <math>\delta\circ\varepsilon=\alpha</math> and <math>\mu\circ\delta=\beta</math>.</ref> in the category '''Ste'''. Surprisingly, this description does not coincide with the construction of closed subspace in the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces.

* Suppose <math>Y</math> is a subset in a stereotype space <math>X</math> endowed with a structure of a stereotype space in such a way that the set-theoretic inclusion <math>Y\subseteq X</math> is a morphism of stereotype spaces (i.e. a continuous linear map). Then <math>Y</math> is called a ''subspace'' of the stereotype space <math>X</math>, with the notation

:<math>Y\hookrightarrow X</math>.

* Suppose we have a chain of stereotype subspaces 

:<math>Z\hookrightarrow Y\hookrightarrow X</math>,

:and the first mapping <math>Z\hookrightarrow Y</math> is a bimorphism of stereotype spaces. Then the space <math>Y</math> is called a ''mediator of the subspace <math>Z</math> in the space <math>X</math>''.

* A subspace <math>Z</math> in a stereotype space <math>X</math> is called an ''immediate subspace'' in <math>X</math>,  with the notation
:<math>Z\overset{\circ}{\hookrightarrow} X</math>,
:if it has no non-trivial mediators, i.e. for any mediator <math>Y</math> of <math>Z</math> in <math>X</math> the inclusion <math>Z\hookrightarrow Y</math> is an isomorphism.

'''Examples:'''

1. An immediate subspace <math>Z</math> in a stereotype space <math>X</math> is said to be ''closed'', if <math>Z</math> (as a set) is closed in <math>X</math> (as a topological space). If <math>Y</math> is a closed subspace in a stereotype space <math>X</math> (as in a locally convex space), then its pseudosaturation <math>Z=Y^\vartriangle</math> is a closed immediate subspace in <math>X</math>. All closed immediate subspaces have this form.
 
2. There are stereotype spaces <math>X</math> with closed immediate subspaces <math>Z=Y^\vartriangle</math> whose topology is not inherited from <math>X</math><ref>In other words, in this case the topology of <math>Y</math> inherited from <math>X</math> is not pseudosaturated.</ref> (this is one of the qualitative differences with the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces).{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=128}}

3. In contrast to the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces in the category '''Ste''' the immediate subspaces are not always closed.{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=128}}

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=134}} ''For any set <math>M</math> in a stereotype space <math>X</math> there is a minimal immediate subspace <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math> in <math>X</math>, containing <math>M</math>:''

::(i) <math>M\subseteq\operatorname{Env}^XM\overset{\circ}{\hookrightarrow} X</math>

::(ii) <math>\forall Z \quad (M\subseteq Z\overset{\circ}{\hookrightarrow} X\ \Rightarrow\ \operatorname{Env}^XM\subseteq Z)</math>,

:''and this subspace <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math> is an immediate subspace in each immediate subspace, containing <math>M</math>:''

::(iii) <math>\forall Z \quad (M\subseteq Z\overset{\circ}{\hookrightarrow} X\ \Rightarrow\ \operatorname{Env}^XM\overset{\circ}{\hookrightarrow} Z)</math>,

* The subspace <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math> is called an ''envelope'' of the set <math>M</math> in the stereotype space <math>X</math>. 

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=131}} ''Each set <math>M</math> in a stereotype space <math>X</math> is a [[total set]]<ref>I.e. the linear span of <math>M</math> is dense in  <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math> (as in a locally convex space).</ref> in its envelope <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math>.''

If <math>{\mathbb C}_M</math> denotes the space of all functions <math>\alpha:M\to{\mathbb C}</math> with finite support, endowed with the strongest locally convex topology, and the mapping <math>\varphi:{\mathbb C}_M\to X</math>  acts by the formula <math>\varphi(\alpha)=\sum_{x\in M}\alpha(x)\cdot x</math>, then the envelope <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM</math> coincides with the [[Envelope (category theory)|abstract categorical envelope]] of the space <math>{\mathbb C}_M</math> in the class <math>\operatorname{Epi}</math> of all epimorphisms in the category '''Ste''' with respect to the morphism <math>\varphi</math>:{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=144}}
: <math>\operatorname{Env}^XM=\operatorname{Env}_\varphi^{\operatorname{Epi}}{\mathbb C}_M</math>

===Immediate quotient spaces and refinements===
Dually, the notion of immediate quotient space gives a "concrete description" of the abstract notion of [[Epimorphism#Related concepts|''immediate epimorphism'']]<ref>An [[epimorphism]] <math>\varepsilon</math> is said to be ''immediate'' if in each representation <math>\varepsilon=\mu\circ\varepsilon'</math>, where <math>\mu</math> is a [[monomorphism]] and <math>\varepsilon'</math> is an epimorphism, the morphism <math>\mu</math> is automatically an [[isomorphism]].</ref>, or, what is equivalent here{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=39}}, [[Epimorphism#Related concepts|strong epimorphism]]<ref>[[File:Diagram-orthogonality-2.jpg|thumb]] An [[epimorphism]] <math>\varepsilon:A\to B</math> is said to be '''strong''', if for any [[monomorphism]] <math>\mu:C\to D</math> and for any morphisms <math>\alpha:A\to C</math> and <math>\beta:B\to D</math> such that <math>\beta\circ\varepsilon=\mu\circ\alpha</math> there exists a morphism <math>\delta:B\to C</math>, such that <math>\delta\circ\varepsilon=\alpha</math> and <math>\mu\circ\delta=\beta</math>.</ref>  in the category '''Ste'''. Like in the situation with monomorphisms, this description does not coincide with the construction of quotient space in the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces.

* Let <math>E</math> be a closed subspace (in the usual sense) in a stereotype space <math>X</math>. Consider a topology <math>\tau</math> on the quotient space <math>X/E</math>, which is majorized by the usual quotient topology of <math>X/E</math>. Let <math>(X/E)^\blacktriangledown</math> be a completion of <math>X/E</math> with respect to the topology <math>\tau</math>. Suppose <math>Y</math> is a subset in the locally convex space <math>(X/E)^\blacktriangledown</math> which contains <math>X/E</math> and at the same time is a stereotype space. Then <math>Y</math> is called a ''quotient space'' of the stereotype space <math>X</math>,  with the notation

:<math>X\rightarrowtail Y</math>.

* Suppose we have two quotient spaces <math>X\rightarrowtail Y</math> and <math> X\rightarrowtail Z</math>. It is said that the <math>Y</math> ''subordinates'' <math>Z</math> (notation: <math>Y\ge Z</math>) if there is a morphism <math>\varkappa:Y\to Z</math> such that <math>\upsilon_Z=\varkappa\circ\upsilon_Y</math> (where <math>\upsilon_Z:X\to Z</math> and <math>\upsilon_Y:X\to Y</math> are the natural mappings).

* Suppose that the quotient space <math>X\rightarrowtail Y</math> subordinates the quotient space <math> X\rightarrowtail Z</math> (i.e. <math>Y\ge Z</math>) and the corresponding morphism <math>\varkappa:Y\to Z</math> is a bimorphism. Then the quotient space <math>Y</math> is called a ''mediator of the quotient space <math>Z</math> of the space <math>X</math>''.

* A quotient space <math>Z</math> of a stereotype space <math>X</math> is called an ''immediate quotient space'' of <math>X</math>, with the notation
:<math>X\overset{\circ}{\rightarrowtail} Z</math>,
:if it has no non-trivial mediators, i.e. for any mediator <math>Y</math> of <math>Z</math> the morphism <math>\varkappa:Y\to Z</math> is an isomorphism.

'''Examples:'''

1. An immediate quotient space <math>Z</math> of a stereotype space <math>X</math> is said to be ''open'', if the corresponding map <math>X\to Z</math> is open<ref>A linear map <math>\varphi:X\to Y</math> is said to be ''open'', if for each neighborhood of zero <math>U\subseteq X</math> there is a neighborhood of zero <math>V\subseteq Y</math> such that <math>\varphi(U)\supseteq V\cap\varphi(X)</math>.</ref>. If <math>E</math> is a closed subspace in a stereotype space <math>X</math>, then the pseudocompletion <math>Z=(X/E)^\triangledown</math> of the (locally convex) quotient space <math>X/E</math> is an open immediate quotient space of <math>X</math>. All open immediate quotient spaces have this form. 

2. There are stereotype spaces <math>X</math> with immediate quotient spaces <math>Z</math> which cannot be represented in the form <math>Z=X/E</math>.{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=138}}  

3. In contrast to the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces in the category '''Ste''' immediate quotient spaces are not always open.{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=138}} 

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=140}} ''For any set <math>F</math> of linear continuous functionals on a stereotype space <math>X</math> there is a minimal immediate quotient space <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math> of <math>X</math> to which all functionals <math>F</math> can be extended:''

::(i) <math>X\overset{\circ}{\rightarrowtail}\operatorname{Ref}^XF\ \&\ (\operatorname{Ref}^XF)^\star\supseteq F</math>

::(ii) <math>\forall Z \quad \big((X\overset{\circ}{\rightarrowtail}Z\ \&\ Z^\star\supseteq F)\ \Rightarrow\ Z\ge\operatorname{Ref}^XF\big)</math>,

:''and this quotient space <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math> is (up to an isomorphism) an immediate quotient space of each immediate quotient space, to which the functionals <math>F</math> are extended:''

::(iii) <math>\forall Z \quad \big((X\overset{\circ}{\rightarrowtail}Z\ \&\ Z^\star\supseteq F)\ \Rightarrow\ Z\overset{\circ}{\rightarrowtail}\operatorname{Ref}^XF\big)</math>.

* The quotient space <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math> is called a ''refinement'' of the set <math>F</math> on the stereotype space <math>X</math>. 

:'''Theorem.'''<ref>This proposition is dual to the corresponding theorem on envelopes in stereotype spaces.</ref> ''Each set <math>F</math> of linear continuous functionals on a stereotype space <math>X</math> is a [[total set]]<ref>I.e. if  <math>y\ne z\in\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math>, then there exists <math>f\in F</math> such that <math>f(y)\ne f(z)</math>.</ref> on its refinement <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math>.''

If <math>{\mathbb C}^F</math> denotes the space of all functions <math>f:M\to{\mathbb C}</math>, endowed with the topology of pointwise convergence, and the mapping <math>\varphi:X\to{\mathbb C}^F</math> acts by the formula <math>\varphi(x)(f)=f(x)</math>, then the refinement <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF</math> coincides with the [[Refinement (category theory)|abstract categorical refinement]] of the space <math>{\mathbb C}^F</math> in the class <math>\operatorname{Mono}</math> of all monomorphisms in the category '''Ste''' by means of the morphism <math>\varphi</math>:{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=144}}
: <math>\operatorname{Ref}^XF=\operatorname{Ref}_\varphi^{\operatorname{Mono}}{\mathbb C}^F</math>

==Category '''Ste''' of stereotype spaces==
The class '''Ste''' of stereotype spaces forms a category with linear continuous maps as morphisms and possesses the following properties:

:* '''Ste''' is [[Pre-abelian category|pre-abelian]]{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=224}};
:*
:* '''Ste''' is [[Complete category|bicomplete]]{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=226}};
:*
:* '''Ste''' is autodual with respect to the functor <math>X\mapsto X^\star</math>{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=220}};
:*
:* '''Ste''' is a [[Nodal decomposition#Categories with nodal decomposition|category with nodal decomposition]]{{sfn|Akbarov|2016|p=142}}.
:*
:* '''Ste''' is a [[*-autonomous category]].{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=245}}

===Kernel and cokernel in the category '''Ste'''===
'''Ste''' is a [[pre-abelian category]]: each morphism <math>\varphi:X\to Y</math> in the category '''Ste''' has a [[Kernel (category theory)|kernel]]
:<math>\operatorname{Ker}\varphi=\{x\in X:\varphi(x)=0\}^\vartriangle=\operatorname{Env}^X\{x\in X:\varphi(x)=0\}</math>
and a [[Cokernel (category theory)|cokernel]]  
:<math>\operatorname{Coker}\varphi=\Big(Y\Big/\overline{\varphi(X)}\Big)^\triangledown=\operatorname{Ref}^Y\{f\in Y^\star:\ f\circ\varphi=0\}.</math>
As a corollary, <math>\varphi</math> has an image <math>\operatorname{Im}\varphi</math> and a coimage <math>\operatorname{Coim}\varphi</math> as well. The following natural identities hold:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=224}}
: <math>
\begin{align}
& (\operatorname{Ker}\varphi)^\star =\operatorname{Coker}(\varphi^\star), & & (\operatorname{Coker}\varphi)^\star =\operatorname{Ker}(\varphi^\star), \\[5pt]
& (\operatorname{Im}\varphi)^\star =\operatorname{Coim}(\varphi^\star), & &
(\operatorname{Coim}\varphi)^\star =\operatorname{Im}(\varphi^\star), \\[5pt]
& (\operatorname{Ker}\varphi)^{\perp} =\operatorname{Im}(\varphi^\star), & & (\operatorname{Im}\varphi)^{\perp} =\operatorname{Ker}(\varphi^\star), \\[5pt]
& \operatorname{Ker}\varphi =(\operatorname{Im}(\varphi^\star))^{\perp}, & & \operatorname{Im}\varphi =(\operatorname{Ker}(\varphi^\star))^{\perp},
\end{align}
</math>
where <math>Q^{\perp}</math> denotes the pseudosaturation of the annihilator of the subspace <math>Q\subseteq P</math> in the dual space <math>P^\star</math>:
: <math>Q^\perp=\{f\in P^\star: \ f|_Q=0\}^\vartriangle=\operatorname{Env}^{P^\star}\{f\in P^\star: \ f|_Q=0\}</math>.

==='''Ste''' as a *-autonomous category===
For any two stereotype spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> the ''stereotype space of operators'' <math>Y\oslash X</math> from <math>X</math> into <math>Y</math>, is defined as the pseudosaturation of the space <math>\operatorname{L}(X,Y)</math> of all linear continuous maps <math>\varphi:X\to Y</math> endowed with the topology of uniform convergeance on totally bounded sets. The space <math>Y\oslash X</math> is stereotype. It defines two natural tensor products

::<math>X\circledast Y:= (X^\star\oslash Y)^\star,</math>

::<math> X\odot Y := Y\oslash X^\star.</math>

:'''Theorem.''' ''In the category  '''Ste''' the following natural identities hold:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=245}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=480-481}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017|p=581}}:''
::<math>\mathbb{C}\circledast X\cong X\cong X\circledast \mathbb{C},
</math>
::<math>
\mathbb{C}\odot X\cong X\cong X\odot\mathbb{C},
</math>
::<math> X\circledast Y\cong Y\circledast X,</math>
::<math>
X\odot Y\cong Y\odot X,
</math>
::<math> (X\circledast Y)\circledast Z\cong X\circledast (Y\circledast Z),</math>
::<math>
(X\odot Y)\odot Z\cong X\odot (Y\odot Z),
</math>
::<math> (X\circledast Y)^\star\cong Y^\star\odot X^\star,</math>
::<math>
(X\odot Y)^\star\cong Y^\star\circledast X^\star,
</math>
::<math>
X\oslash Y\cong Y^\star\oslash X^\star,
</math>
::<math> 
X\oslash (Y\circledast Z)\cong (X\oslash Y)\oslash Z,</math>
::<math>
(X\odot Y)\oslash Z\cong X\odot(Y\oslash Z).
</math>
:''In particular, '''Ste''' is a [[symmetric monoidal category]] with respect to the bifunctor <math>\odot</math>, a [[closed monoidal category|closed]] [[symmetric monoidal category]] with respect to the bifunctor <math>\circledast</math> and the internal hom-functor <math>\oslash</math>, and a [[*-autonomous category]]:''
::<math>X^{\star\star}\cong X,</math>
::<math> 
X^\star\oslash (Y\circledast Z)\cong (X\circledast Y)^\star\oslash Z.</math>

'''Examples:'''

1. If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are [[Fréchet spaces]], then their stereotype tensor product <math>X\circledast Y</math> coincides with the usual projective tensor product <math>X\hat{\otimes}Y</math> of locally convex spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=7.17}}

2. If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are [[Fréchet spaces]] and at least one of them possesses the (classical) [[approximation property]], then their stereotype tensor product <math>X\odot Y</math> coincides with the usual injective tensor product <math>X\check{\otimes}Y</math> of locally convex spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|loc=7.21}}

===Limits and colimits in the category '''Ste'''===
'''Ste''' is a [[Complete category|bicomplete]] category: each small diagram <math>F:J\to\,</math>'''Ste''' has a [[direct limit|limit]], <math>\lim_{j\to\infty}F_j</math>, which coincides with the pseudocompletion of the corresponding limit in the category '''LocConv''' of locally convex spaces 
:<math>\lim_{j\to\infty}F_j=\Big(\overset{\operatorname{\bf LocConv}}{\lim_{j\to\infty}}F_j\Big)^\triangledown</math>, 
and a [[inverse limit|colimit]], <math>\lim_{\infty\gets j}F_j</math>, which coincides with the pseudosaturation of the corresponding colimit in '''LocConv'''
:<math>\lim_{\infty\gets j}F_j=\Big(\overset{\operatorname{\bf LocConv}}{\lim_{\infty\gets j}}F_j\Big)^\vartriangle</math>. 
However, the [[Coproduct (category theory)|direct sum]] and the [[Product (category theory)|direct product]] in '''Ste''' coincide with the corresponding constructions in '''LocConv''':
:<math>
\bigoplus_{i\in I} X_i=\overset{\operatorname{\bf LocConv}}{\bigoplus_{i\in I}} X_i,\quad \prod_{i\in I} X_i=\overset{\operatorname{\bf LocConv}}{\prod_{i\in I}X_i}.
</math>
The following natural identities hold:{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=245}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017|p=581}}
:<math>
\Big(\bigoplus_{i\in I} X_i\Big)^\star\cong \prod_{i\in I} X_i^\star
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\prod_{i\in I} X_i\Big)^\star\cong \bigoplus_{i\in I} X_i^\star
</math>
:<math>
Y\oslash \Big(\bigoplus_{i\in I} X_i\Big)\cong \prod_{i\in I} ( Y\oslash X_i)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\prod_{j\in J} Y_j\Big)\oslash X\cong \prod_{j\in J} ( Y_j\oslash X)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\bigoplus_{i\in I} X_i\Big)\circledast \Big(\bigoplus_{j\in J} Y_j\Big) \cong \bigoplus_{i\in I,j\in J} ( X_i\circledast Y_j)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\prod_{i\in I} X_i\Big)\odot \Big(\prod_{j\in J} Y_j\Big) \cong \prod_{i\in I,j\in J} ( X_i\odot Y_j)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\lim_{i\to\infty} X_i\Big)^\star\cong \lim_{\infty\gets i} X_i^\star
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\lim_{\infty\gets i} X_i\Big)^\star\cong \lim_{i\to\infty} X_i^\star
</math>
:<math>
Y\oslash \Big(\lim_{i\to\infty} X_i\Big)\cong \lim_{\infty\gets i} (Y\oslash X_i)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\lim_{\infty\gets j} Y_j\Big)\oslash X\cong \lim_{\infty\gets j} (Y_j\oslash X)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\lim_{i\to\infty} X_i\Big)\circledast \Big(\lim_{j\to\infty} Y_j\Big) \cong \lim_{i,j\to\infty} ( X_i\circledast Y_j)
</math>
:<math>
\Big(\lim_{\infty\gets i} X_i\Big)\odot \Big(\lim_{\infty\gets j} Y_j\Big) \cong \lim_{\infty\gets i,j} ( X_i\odot Y_j)
</math>

===Grothendieck transformation===

If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are stereotype spaces then for each elements <math>x\in X</math> and <math>y\in Y</math> the formula 
::<math>
(x\circledast y)(\varphi)=\varphi(y)(x),\qquad \varphi\in X^\star\oslash Y
</math>
defines an ''elementary tensor'' <math>x\circledast y\in X\circledast Y=(X^\star\oslash Y)^\star</math>, and the formula
::<math>
(x\odot y)(f)=f(x)\cdot y,\qquad f\in X^\star
</math>
defines an ''elementary tensor'' <math>x\odot y\in X\odot Y=Y\oslash X^\star</math>

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=246}} ''For each stereotype spaces  <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> there is a unique linear continuous map <math>\Gamma_{X,Y}: X\circledast Y\to X\odot Y</math> which turns elementary tensors <math>x\circledast y</math> into elementary tensors'' <math>x\odot y</math>:
::<math>
\Gamma_{X,Y}(x\circledast y)=x\odot y,\qquad x\in X, \ y\in Y.
</math>
:''The family of maps <math>\Gamma_{X,Y}: X\circledast Y\to X\odot Y</math> defines a natural transformation of the bifunctor <math>\circledast</math> into the bifunctor <math>\odot</math>''.

*The map <math>\Gamma_{X,Y}</math> is called the ''Grothendieck transformation''.

===Stereotype approximation property===
A stereotype space <math>X</math> is said to have the ''stereotype approximation property'', if each linear continuous map <math>\varphi:X\to X</math> can be approximated in the stereotype space of operators <math>X\oslash X</math> by the linear continuous maps of finite rank. This condition is weaker than the existence of the [[Schauder basis]], but formally stronger than the classical [[approximation property]] (however, it is not clear (2017) whether the stereotype approximation property coincides with the classical one, or not). 

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=264}} ''For a stereotype space <math>X</math> the following conditions are equivalent:''  
::(i) <math>X</math> ''has the stereotype approximation property;''
::(ii) ''the Grothendieck transformation <math>\Gamma_{X,X^\star}:X\circledast X^\star\to X\odot X^\star</math> is a monomorphism (in the category '''Ste''');''
::(iii) ''the Grothendieck transformation <math>\Gamma_{X,X^\star}:X\circledast X^\star\to X\odot X^\star</math> is an epimorphism (in the category '''Ste''');''
::(iv) ''for any stereotype space <math>Y</math> the Grothendieck transformation <math>\Gamma_{X,Y}:X\circledast Y\to X\odot Y</math> is a monomorphism (in the category '''Ste''');''
::(v) ''for any stereotype space <math>Y</math> the Grothendieck transformation <math>\Gamma_{X,Y}:X\circledast Y\to X\odot Y</math> is an epimorphism (in the category '''Ste''').''

:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=265}} ''If two stereotype spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> have the stereotype approximation property, then the spaces <math>X\oslash Y</math>, <math>X\circledast Y</math> and <math>X\odot Y</math> have the stereotype approximation property as well.''

In particular, if <math>X</math> has the stereotype approximation property, then the same is true for <math>X^\star</math> and for <math>X\oslash X</math>.

===Universality of tensor product===
For any stereotype spaces <math>X</math>, <math>Y</math>, <math>Z</math> a bilinear map <math>\beta:X\times Y\to Z</math> is said to be ''continuous'' (as a bilinear map of stereotype spaces) if 

: 1) for each neighborhood of zero <math>W\subseteq Z</math> and for each compact set <math>S\subseteq X</math> there exists a neighborhood of zero <math>V\subseteq Y</math>  such that <math>\beta(S,V)\subseteq W</math>, and

: 2) for each neighborhood of zero <math>W\subseteq Z</math> and for each compact set <math>T\subseteq Y</math> there exists a neighborhood of zero <math>U\subseteq X</math> such that <math>\beta(U,T)\subseteq W</math>.

'''Examples:'''

1. For any stereotype space <math>X</math> the pairing <math>(x,f)\in X\times X^\star\to f(x)\in {\mathbb C}</math> is a continuous bilinear map.

2. For any two stereotype spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> the map <math>(x,y)\in X\times Y\to x\circledast y\in X\circledast Y</math> is a continuous bilinear map.

3. For any two stereotype spaces <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> the map <math>(x,y)\in X\times Y\to x\odot y\in X\odot Y</math> is a continuous bilinear map.

[[File:Universality-circledast.jpg|thumb]]
:'''Theorem.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=242}} ''For any stereotype spaces <math>X</math>, <math>Y</math>, <math>Z</math> and for any continuous bilinear map <math>\beta:X\times Y\to Z</math> there exists a unique continuous linear map <math>\widetilde{\beta}:X\circledast Y\to Z</math> such that <math>\widetilde{\beta}\circ\iota=\beta</math>, where <math>\iota(x,y)=x\circledast y, \ x\in X, \ y\in Y</math>.''

:'''Corollary.'''{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=265}} ''For any stereotype space <math>X</math> the pairing <math>(x,f)\in X\times X^\star\to f(x)\in {\mathbb C}</math> has a unique extension to a linear continuous functional <math>\operatorname{cont}:X\circledast X^\star\to{\mathbb C}</math>. This functional in its turn can be represented as a trace of the operators <math>\varphi:X\to X</math> occurring as images of the tensors <math>\alpha\in X\circledast X^\star</math> under the Grothendieck transformation <math>\Gamma_{X,X^\star}: X\circledast X^\star\to X\odot X^\star=X\oslash X</math> if and only if the space <math>X</math> has the stereotype approximation property.''

==Applications==

Being a [[symmetric monoidal category]], '''Ste''' generates the notions of a ''[[stereotype algebra]]'' (as a [[Monoid (category theory)|monoid]] in '''Ste''') and a ''[[Stereotype_algebra#Stereotype_modules|stereotype module]]'' (as a module in '''Ste''' over such a monoid), and it turns out that for each stereotype algebra <math>A</math> the categories <sub><math>A</math></sub>'''Ste''' and '''Ste'''<sub><math>A</math></sub> of left and right stereotype modules over <math>A</math> have the structure of [[Enriched category|enriched categories]] over '''Ste'''.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=289}} This distinguishes the category '''Ste''' from the other known categories of locally convex spaces, since up to the recent time only the category '''Ban''' of Banach spaces and the category '''Fin''' of finite-dimensional spaces had been known to possess this property. On the other hand, the category '''Ste''' is so wide, and the tools for creating new spaces in '''Ste''' are so diverse, that this suggests the idea that all the results of functional analysis can be reformulated inside the stereotype theory without essential losses. On this way one can even try to completely replace the category of locally convex spaces in analysis (and in related areas) by the category '''Ste''' of stereotype spaces with the view of possible simplifications – this program was announced by S. Akbarov in 2005{{sfn|Akbarov|2005}} and the following results can be considered as evidences of its reasonableness:

:* In the theory of stereotype spaces the approximation property is inherited by the spaces of operators and by tensor products. This allows to reduce the list of counterexamples in comparison with the Banach theory, where as is known the space of operators does not inherit the approximation property.{{sfn|Szankowski|1981}}
:*
:* The arising theory of stereotype algebras allows to simplify constructions in the duality theories for non-commutative groups. In particular, the [[Group algebra#Stereotype group algebras|group algebras]] (and their [[Envelope (category theory)|envelopes]] in the necessary cases) in these theories become [[Hopf algebra]]s in the standard algebraic sense.{{sfn|Akbarov|2003|p=278}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2009|p=507}}{{sfn|Kuznetsova|2013}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}} 
:*
:* This in its turn leads to a family of generalizations of the [[Pontryagin duality]] based on the notion of [[Envelope (category theory)|envelope]]: the  holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous envelopes of stereotype algebras give rise respectively to the holomorphic, the smooth and the continuous dualities in ''big geometric disciplines'' – [[complex geometry]], [[differential geometry]], and [[topology]] – for certain classes of (not necessarily commutative) topological groups considered in these disciplines ([[affine algebraic group]]s, and some classes of [[Lie group]]s and Moore groups).{{sfn|Akbarov|2009}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2016}}{{sfn|Akbarov|2017}}{{sfn|Kuznetsova|2013}}
